claim: 7 is both a prime and a natural number

supporting.text: 7 is divisible only by 1 and itself, which is the definition of a prime number.

attacks.text: 7 is divisible only by 1 and itself, which is the definition of a prime number.
The definition of a prime number excludes 1, but 7 is not 1, so this argument is redundant.
Redundancy does not invalidate correctness; the argument still holds as 7 meets the prime number definition.

supporting.text: 7 is a positive integer greater than 1, fulfilling the criteria for a natural number.

attacks.text: 7 is a positive integer greater than 1, fulfilling the criteria for a natural number.
The definition of natural numbers sometimes excludes 0, but 7 is still included in all definitions.
Even if natural numbers are defined to start from 0, 7 remains a natural number as it is a positive integer.

supporting.text: The set of natural numbers includes all positive integers starting from 1, and 7 is part of this set.

attacks.text: The set of natural numbers includes all positive integers starting from 1, and 7 is part of this set.
Some mathematical definitions include 0 as a natural number, which could exclude 7 if the definition is not strictly positive integers.
Standard mathematical conventions overwhelmingly define natural numbers as positive integers starting from 1, making the inclusion of 0 a minority view.
The argument does not address the primality of 7, only its natural number status.
The primality of 7 is well-established and uncontroversial in mathematics, so the argument's focus on natural numbers does not weaken the overall claim.

supporting.text: Mathematical consensus defines prime numbers as natural numbers greater than 1 with no positive divisors other than 1 and themselves, which applies to 7.

attacks.text: Mathematical consensus defines prime numbers as natural numbers greater than 1 with no positive divisors other than 1 and themselves, which applies to 7.
Some alternative definitions of prime numbers include 1 as a prime, which would make 7 not uniquely prime.
The modern mathematical consensus explicitly excludes 1 from prime numbers, making the alternative definition outdated and incorrect.
If considering non-standard number systems (e.g., modular arithmetic), 7 might not behave as a prime in certain contexts.
The claim explicitly refers to classical arithmetic, where 7 is universally recognized as prime, making non-standard contexts irrelevant.
